data.text: Anyone Using Bicycle Trailer instead of Panniers for Touring?
Is there anybody travelling with a bicycle trailer instead of carrying the luggage on the bike itself. And what is your experience ?
Looks like a pain in the ass while climbing üòÖ
data.author: Laurens Laurens

data.text: because your center of gravity is very low it climbs very wel actually.
data.author: Ard Nagtegaal

data.text: Have had the Bob Ibex for years. Absolutely love it on the bigger, longer tours. Soft sand is an issue, and it is an extra few kgs for the actual hardware... So depends on the route
data.author: Ray D. Chaplin

data.text: Worth a try- i use a trailer and small panniers on the rear tire- more maneuverable-
data.author: Keith Michael Larsen

data.text: It is very useful for carrying big loads with no so big effort, but it involves pedaling always seated so finally your ass suffers too much. I used it in my first long trip and for following trips I prefer 4 saddles.
data.author: Iker Etxeberria Bilbao

data.text: why can you not peddle upright?
data.author: Ingrid Wouters

data.text: if you balance the bike, even if it is very slightly, the trailer starts turning/balancing and you can not control the bike.
data.author: Iker Etxeberria Bilbao

data.text: thanks for explaining!
data.author: Ingrid Wouters

data.text: I use a trailer but I prefer the two wheeled system
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: It's alot easier for having a balanced load, and not having to split up your gear, like you can often throw like your hiking bag with mat and tent strapped to it into the trailer which makes transitioning from bike to hike easier. You gotta watch how much weight you pack vs the trailer rating of your hitch. Another thing is if it's an axle mount trailer, I've snapped an axle before but it was when I was living out of my bike trailer with my dog and we had an ass load of gear between us. Trailers generally are better for flatter rides because like they change the way you crest hills or bumpy trails etc
data.author: Stu Pitts Atkins

data.text: I was thinking of getting a trailer to take my small dog with me but I think it would stress her to much she is so spoiled
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: as long as it's physically comfortable for them they usually love it. Like mine would jump into the trailer when I would unload gear out of it like let's go but he's also giant. But once they realize like oh this is a very slow vehicle and I can stick my head out and smell they usually love the idea
data.author: Stu Pitts Atkins

data.text: I towed a trailer for 400 miles for Dover to Lands end ,then a further 350 from Lands end to Telford. I have now sold it. I wont be using one again.its great for keeping the weight low down but, care needs to be taken balancing the load. Braking is interesting, as is descending or ascending steep hills. Gone back to the more traditional panniers and thereby, keeping rhe weight much lower
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I've been out with a bob yak and cycled very nice with a low gravity point . Runs behind you very smoothly too . With low speeds and parking the bike is a bit more difficult . And you are often not allowed on the train with a bicycle car either, so if you want to go to the beach somewhere and continue by train, you have to do it secretly haha . Either disassemble the wheel and fork or something and take that as luggage . Other than that it's a little heavier but if you have a lot of bags on the bike it won't matter a lot I think .
data.author: Ard Nagtegaal

data.text: ..I traveled with my Woman partner by bicycle, from Pennsylvania USA to Utah USA, during 2011. She pulled a BOB trailer similar to the trailer in the image. She pulled it most every day, I pulled it sometimes. My preference is to use luggage on the bike itself. I like the way ‚Äúluggage on the bike itself‚Äù ‚Ä¶feels to me‚Ä¶also, there are parking issues, ‚Äúalternate forms of transportation‚Äù issues, (racks, autos, trains, busses, taxi, Uber, airplane)..‚Äúclimbing steps‚Äù issues, different size tires logistics‚Ä¶the actual ‚Äúpulling the trailer‚Äù was a preference thing, I like the weight of my gear to be more dispersed over the entire frame of the bicycle, relative to my position on the frame, as opposed to having most weight trailing behind me, especially up, and down, hills‚Ä¶I have been using a 2 wheeled Burley trailer around town for 4 decades..a very good tool for my bicycling lifestyle
data.author: Michael J Lewis

data.text: I bought a BOB trailer thinking it would be so great for touring but later decided the extra weight and the logistics of transporting it by plane, in addition to my bicycle, would be a problem when traveling overseas. Just my bike and luggage easily reaches standard weight limits. Also, if you plan to take your bike onto a train or a boat during your cycling route, it's easier with just a bike. So I went cycle touring with pannier bags and was glad I did. In fact, with each successive trip, I took less luggage. Less weight really does make a difference to me. My trailer has only been used for local duties, carrying things home from shops.
data.author: Paul McMahon

data.text: Very well stated, Paul.
data.author: Richard Cheatham

data.text: Thanks.
data.author: Paul McMahon

data.text: yes well stated, I have a topeak, great for doing loops from where I live, or taking ferry , as long as I dump the car in Dover or Portsmouth. great when my wife goes with me get all the stuff in the trailer. However when it comes to trains they are a no no.
data.author: Tony Kilcoyne

data.text: I had a Bob and road 4000 miles from Fairbanks Alaska to the Grand Canyon. Also had two bags. I loved it
data.author: Gordon Williams

data.text: I‚Äôve had three different trailers over the last 20 years. Your conclusions are exactly the same as mine. It‚Äôs very handy for around town trips.
data.author: Mike McAuley

data.text: I love the concept of the bicycle trailer and they can be very useful. I actually really like my BOB trailer and it's fun to ride around town with it on flat roads. I just don't see any advantages for me personally in taking it on a long distance tour. Even without the logistics issue, it adds around 6 or 7 kilograms to the load and, for me, lighter is better and riding is more enjoyable with less weight.
data.author: Paul McMahon

data.text: Makes sense.
data.author: Von Ketelsen

data.text: I second all this feedback on the BOB. I really like mine and was excited to tour with it but after a trial run I realised I prefer panniers. It‚Äôs great for going to the shops tho! And I can see that maybe on a flat tour on all roads it could be good.
data.author: Mike Thomason

data.text: Trailers are great for flat countries like Holland where I live. When I cycled through Germany I installed a smaller chainwheel for my Rohloff so I could do steep climbs. But it took ages to reach the top. I own three good bicycles, each special for its task, a light Koga Miyata racing bike with 3-speed drum brake hubs, a strong heavy touring bike with a Rohloff Speedhub (1990 German CroMo ECS prototype) and a light Cannondale Bad Boy for other fun things. Plus an old Giant Bronco in the Philippines which I use when I'm living there. Invest in diversity.
data.author: J√∂rg Duurkoop

data.text: We tested this in the past week and were very pleased. Excellent in all terrains including single track.
data.author: Clair Numberi

data.text:
I don't consider them cargo, but they are in a trailer üòÉ https://pedals4paws.com
Pedals4Paws - Bike Touring With Dogs
pedals4paws.com
data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: I‚Äôve used and highly recommend bob trailer for touring on a tandem because it gives the space you need with great stability. I‚Äôve tried them some on single bikes, and believe it adds to much weight to your rig. My opinion, keep the overall weight of kit as low as possible makes a better tourüòâüö¥‚Ä¶.
data.author: Curtis Patak

data.text: We crossed USA with tandem and Bob Yak. Worked well because roads wide and empty on the whole (easy to avoid cities). Would have been very heavy, much more strain on the bike, if all the luggage had been in panniers etc. Esp when we needed to carry extra water in the deserts üèú
data.author: Tim Start

data.text: Yes, the Bob is great with tandem, also greater than the attention and interest you get touring solo ,the tandem/Bob is a huge head turner. A true magnet for trail magic üòâüö¥üö¥‚Ä¶..
data.author: Curtis Patak

data.text: UniTrekker bags don‚Äôt hit the ground
data.author: Don Haueter Jr.

data.text: I have one to sell üòÖ brand new
data.author: Roch Malnuit

data.text: Depending on the weight you're carrying it'll take a day or two to adjust but worth it
data.author: Hector Maclennan

data.text: I had a BOB, I sold it and got a Burley Nomad. there are pros and cons to both, but the biggest pros, in my opinion for the Burley is that the tongue and wheels come off easily and stow in the trailer, the upper structure collapses and they sell a bag to put the whole works into. I checked my setup in this packed configuration, it is under the size and weight limits for most carriers. One will usually have to pay extra for the bike, but not this trailer.
data.author: Dennis Peterson

data.text: My Burley Nomad on roads and my Bob for off road and single track.
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: had done a long trip with one. Fast rolling, no load on your bike or back
data.author: John Mellor

data.text: I had one on my first tour, I was inexperienced. I sold it and moved to panniers front and rear. I regret that decision. What I found most convenient with the trailer was not having to dig to the bottom of my pannier to find whatever you need, only because everything you need is always at the bottom of the third pannier lol. The trailer was great, one zip and everything is in plain sight. It handled very well. Drawbacks for me was when I got out of the saddle and pushed hard the bike kept rocking forwards/backwards. This was cured by weight distribution. Another drawback is all the mass is placed on the rear bike tire and it wore out prematurely. Overall, I miss it.
data.author: Jeff Martin

data.text: I know someone who died when he was going uphill and the weight of the trailer caused his bike to flip over backwards, he died
data.author: Tara Hayes

data.text: They're great if you're staying on paved roads the while time..
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: Hm
data.author: Jonathan Gregore

data.text: Pulled a Burley Nomad trailer across America, 15 years ago. Was able to take a guitar along. But felt like an anchor, on some hills
data.author: Von Ketelsen

data.text: I have only used panniers. These things can 'wag your bike'.
data.author: Vella Damian

data.text: Yes I do travel with a BOB Yak trailer when I'm not climbing big mountain, I find the trailer not so good there. +flexible loading capability, it's transfer on airplane as luggage if you take swingarm and wheel of and pack it up into the trailer.
data.author: Thore Burapa Pedersen

data.text: There is a cheap Chinese copy of the BOB I can recommend. It can be folded for easy transport. I myself have a real Bob, too, but the floor was badly brazed and I had to fix it with tie wraps. Also its dissel broke and had to have it welded. The wheel is too small, I couldn't even cross a railroad with it. But it adds some safety on wet roads. When you get into a slip it stabilises the bike and I avoided some crashes.
data.author: J√∂rg Duurkoop

data.text: ,my BOB has been true hell and back and still in one piece. And you right with wet roads, I had a couple of slips on my front but trailer saved me. Love the BOB except of when I'm in steep mountains,happy cycling to ya....
data.author: Thore Burapa Pedersen

data.text: Hills with a trailer are not a problem either up or down; this is the top of the Pyrenees. I crossed from France to Spain at Somport, camped at Canfranc Estacion - tour in 2004.
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: Here from the Spanish side on the way to Jaca
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: Here in Spain...
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: Lescun, French Pyrenees
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: Rim brakes and nothing special to see, here.
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: on the group somebody said that you have to keep sitting on the saddle because of balance problems, is that also your experience?
data.author: Ingrid Wouters

data.text: There's no need to keep sitting in the saddle. The bike responds to a rider's input a fraction of a second more slowly with a trailer is all. That feels weird for about 20 minutes, then you adjust automatically and it ceases to be noticeable.
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: thank you very good info!
data.author: Ingrid Wouters

data.text: Buy a Burley Coho XC.
data.author: Dirk Wellmann

data.text: In use of this one
data.author: Carl Coussens

data.text: might be a few comments useful for you
data.author: Mathew Ellison
Pahan Dulanja
Pahan Dulanja

data.text: I have a burley flat bed... I don't use it all the time, but i like it for big loads... It also packs quite flat and fast for train or bus transport
data.author: Cristi Gheorghe

data.text: Yes Ingrid, i used my Topeak Journey trailer in Uganda, Bosnia, Algarve and now brussels - istanbul. I love it. Traler and bag weigh only 6kgs. It has a lot of storage capacity, does not take wind, one wheel for single tracks... Only advantages. If you wanna try it, you're welcome as of early August. I live in Wezembeek-oppem.
data.author: Luc Somers

data.text: thanks for the invitation. I would really like to try it! I live close by in Halle so I will contact you beginning of August !
data.author: Ingrid Wouters

data.text: Ok Ingrid, i return 3/8. You can contact me as of 4/8 via WhatsApp on +32-486-439.083 Cheers, Luc
data.author: Luc Somers

data.text: No one seems to mention one critical aspect of trailers. This can become very difficult to maneuver when riding downhill at high speeds. As it does not have a brake of its own, trying to brake with the bike can and will be a struggle if speed is not maintained. The trailer will continue to move forward with weight and it will almost try to overpass if speed is not contained. This is one experience no one thinks of unless they under go such extremes. Very frightenting for none experienced and very well serves to watch speed with trailers on downhill runs. Other than that, great stuff.
data.author: Hans Kang

data.text: I only use it locally if I need to bring som big item home from a shop. It feels too incovenient and obstructing to use it for a long tour which will always include a lot of hills.
data.author: Kjell Hamran Vegge √òdeg√•rd

data.text: Started our round the world tour with on at the end of March from Scotland. We lasted until Prague and shipped it back to the UK. Great idea and I'm sure it has uses, but it just didn't work out practically for us.
data.author: The Gullivers Travels

data.text: Did thousand with a bob. Having the front end light makes a huge difference offroad and i toured offroad extenseively. The low center of gravity is sweet and if it high centers, it drags like a sled. I welded a small triangle before the wheel and it hopped curbs and cut a rack down so my cook kit had its own area. Overweight alot and the mesh repairs great with twine. It was even stronger. Lastly, i removed the tube and cut off the beed of a child‚Äôs tyre and fit it in. Even overweight i went without a tube for years no prob. Get one.
data.author: Kenny Barks

data.text: Around 4,000 miles on a burley Nomad. No problem in the midwest(USA). However, I‚Äôve never had to fly with it. Interestingly I‚Äôm doing a week, next week with just panniers for the first time in a long time. Just for fun. I‚Äôll report back:)
data.author: Brad Lufkin

data.text: It is possible to take almost all your possessions if you want‚Ä¶it will only take more effort. Like an RV with a trailer behind it
